Answer: There's only one answer:Let me qualify this: I'm half Italian - half American and have lived in both those countries. I also lived in Germany and Portugal, as well as traveled to most of Europe. Been to Spain plenty, and speak Spanish well. Holidays were often spent in Croatia, in the 90's. Also been to France a lot, and speak fluent French.And I now live in the UK, in London.All of that to say this much: I've been exposed to a lot, both living and touring, and as far as I am concerned,There's only one answer:Let me qualify this: I'm half Italian - half American and have lived in both those countries. I also lived in Germany and Portugal, as well as traveled to most of Europe. Been to Spain plenty, and speak Spanish well. Holidays were often spent in Croatia, in the 90's. Also been to France a lot, and speak fluent French.And I now live in the UK, in London.All of that to say this much: I've been exposed to a lot, both living and touring, and as far as I am concerned,I lived in Ireland for nearly 4 years, and let me tell you... you won't find a people so eager to get to know you, help you out, and drink you under the table, as the Irish.And they all seem to know each other, even in a city like Dublin. There's no "six degrees of separation" here; it's more like "2 degrees", because it seems there's always "a friend of mine who does know 'yer man' Paddy."In rural Ireland, it's even more marked. If you're going around looking for an address, and stop to ask someone, they'll most likely tell you, "Nevermind that - who ye lookin' fer?"... and they'll point you in the right direction. Personal experience, and not just mine.Here's another personal experience. My first night in Dublin, after moving there, I went to the local pub next to the hotel where I was staying. The Six Nations Rugby tournament was going on. As much as I liked watching it, I couldn't understand why it was being played the way it was.This must have been obvious on my face, as one fella turned to me and said, "Yer not makin' any sense o' this, are ya? Sure, look... see yer man with the ball?… now, he has to…" and explained everything... amidst I can't remember HOW many pints of Guinness which I was never asked to order or pay for (and I did offer to)!And how about this one? My wife and I were on vacation in Galway, visiting as tourists; this was about 2 years before we actually moved to Ireland. We hadn't booked any hotels, we'd just come in by train from Dublin, and we were trying to get our bearings on the map. An elderly lady well into her 70's (if not early 80’s), carrying shopping bags came up to us, asking if we were lost.We told her we were just trying to figure out in which directions the hotels were, on the map. She looked at us, and said, "Look, my son's away for the week-end, and I'm by myself in the house. If the two of ye want a room, you're welcome to keep me company!"And we did! Her name was Carmel, bless her... and she even made us breakfast the next morning. Wonder if she’s even still alive? This was over 15 years ago; I never did go back to check, though I remember exactly where her house is.That said, even today - more than 10 years after I’ve left Ireland - the closest, dearest friends I have kept in my circle are the Irish ones I made in my time living there… still today. Anyhow, all this to tell you… the nicest and friendliest people you'll ever meet are in

Answer: This February my wife was diagnosed and given six months to live. When I heard the doctor tell her “six months”, it felt likeI met my wife, Jess, twenty-one years ago when she was nineteen.Our parents owned side-by-side cabins in the northern part of New York and we both happened to be along for the week-long hunting trip our fathers planned that year.Jess' father was a skilled hunter and could hit a headshot from a mile away — same as my dad.Jess and I didn't hunt with them — we hung out by the lake.The moment I saw Jess I fell in lThis February my wife was diagnosed and given six months to live. When I heard the doctor tell her “six months”, it felt likeI met my wife, Jess, twenty-one years ago when she was nineteen.Our parents owned side-by-side cabins in the northern part of New York and we both happened to be along for the week-long hunting trip our fathers planned that year.Jess' father was a skilled hunter and could hit a headshot from a mile away — same as my dad.Jess and I didn't hunt with them — we hung out by the lake.The moment I saw Jess I fell in love. We've been together ever since.But now, now that she has an expiration date, I just don't know what to do — I'm scared and lost.Monday morning at work I was telling my best friend and supervisor, Timmy, about my wife's condition. Timmy told me that I.T. or Intelligent Terrestrial just came out with their latest models.These models are different than those of yesteryear because they are 52% mechanical and 48% biological.Timmy said all you have to do is mail a sample of DNA to I.T. and upload a digital copy of your consciousness through an app. You can then purchase a custom made clone at an age of your choice. When the clone arrives it will turn on, study it's surroundings and await a consciousness download.“Oh my God Timmy, what's the catch?”“The price, Leon.”When I got home from work, Jess and I plugged in and uploaded a digital copy of our entire conscious catalog to I.T. and then mailed off DNA samples.Jess asked me what age I wanted her to be. It felt awkward to say “twenty”, but I did it — I was honest. I miss her smooth, youthful skin and I want her to be young and healthy — especially if I have to cash my entire 401K in to afford it.We told her parents that we were going to basically bring her back from the dead and her father threatened to shoot any abomination that we brought into this world.One month later, on a day that Jess was particularly ill, the doorbell rang.Jess and I dragged the box through the door and laid it on the living room floor. I gently cut along the lines and when I opened the flaps, there,she,was.The last time my heart fluttered like this was the day I met her.Jess helped me lift I.T. out of the box and sit I.T. up.I.T. was warm and soft. I.T. was mine. I paid for I.T. I own I.T.Machines like this don't have rights — even though they are part biological, the governments recognize them in the same way they would a lawnmower — so, as I said, I.T. is my possession.The science behind uploading a digital consciousness is so cutting edge, that the laws just haven't caught up yet.Jess turned I.T. on and I.T. looked right into my eyes. I was in love — with two women, but, it was the same woman. We hadn't uploaded Jess' consciousness yet, so, I.T. was running on basic programming, but I.T. was gorgeous.Jess asked me what I wanted to do, and for the first time in a very long time — I lied to her.I told her we should go shopping and buy I.T. some clothes.I.T. doesn't seem to have a personality yet.“Hello…. Smile…”Jess picked outfits for both of them and we went for a walk through the park together. It was amazing — I was so happy.We walked down a cozy little trail and found a tuck away to sit and talk.I.T. watched and studied every move Jess and I made. I.T. was learning and adapting.I.T. was becoming aware.At one point Jess and I got distracted and I.T. wandered off. When we found I.T., I.T. was gazing at the sky.I asked I.T. what it was doing. I.T. said, “Where do I come from?”“You come from Heaven. You are my angel.”That answer seemed to work for I.T. We all walked back to the car and headed home.When we got home, Jess immediately started coughing. She fell to the ground and I tried to help her, but I didn't know what to do.Jess passed away right then. It was finally over.I called her family and the police. It took an hour for them to remove the body. I had Jess 2.0 sitting in my back room waiting for them to leave.After the police left, I plugged I.T. into my laptop and downloaded Jess' consciousness.After the download was complete, we walked outside and I looked into her gigantic brown eyes. I asked her, “Is it you, Jess?”She smiled and said, “It is, silly — now kiss me.”Her head slammed back. I didn't know if she was glitching or what and then I heard a bang and saw a hole above her left eye.My beautiful Jessica died twice today. I was crushed.Over the next two decades, I fell into a deep, dark, alcohol-fueled depression. Although I had developed a serious alcohol problem, I was able to work and save every single penny I earned.After twenty years of saving, I decided I wanted both of them back — the twenty-year-old Jess and the forty-year-old Jess.I sent my entire life savings off to I.T. and in one month, my doorbell rang.I cut the box open and wept when I saw my angel(s).I turned them on.I also clothed them. The younger version of me may have left them in the nude, but at this age, I just want my companion(s) back.The ladies helped me back to my room to lay down. I was so tired from all the excitement.I've waited and worked an entire lifetime to be with the woman I love. And now, at long last — she is beside me.I died, on that very night as a happy man.One day later, the doorbell rang. It seems my beautiful Jessicas used my direct deposit life insurance benefit to make a purchase.They gently cut the box open.And turned me on.You ask where technology will be in 2050?We will be everywhere.LeonSpecial thanks:Cameron — Dear friend. Thank you so much for all your help with bringing this idea to life. You are awesome. I'm proud to call you friend.Kinsalynn — My sister and friend. Your help with makeup and photography was an absolute godsend — thank you so much. I love and appreciate you. P.S. you took over 300 pictures in an eight hour span. Thank you from the bottom of my heart:)Brooke — Even with a bullet hole in the head, you are deliciously gorgeous. You spent eight hours modeling for my Quora answer today and never once did you fail to impress or inspire me. I am honored to be friends with you.Jess —

Answer: My grandmother is now 93, I am 42 and so the age difference is pretty much close to me to the one you suggested, taking into account that the speed of innovation is accelerating the analogy may be just right.So she was born in 1926 in a small village. There was no water plumbing nor electric network. No public transportation nor even what you would call a road.Growing up she was sent to school to learn to read and write and do math. Meanwhile most houses in town received water and electricity from the services.She grown up and got married. As her and grandpa began building a family they got aMy grandmother is now 93, I am 42 and so the age difference is pretty much close to me to the one you suggested, taking into account that the speed of innovation is accelerating the analogy may be just right.So she was born in 1926 in a small village. There was no water plumbing nor electric network. No public transportation nor even what you would call a road.Growing up she was sent to school to learn to read and write and do math. Meanwhile most houses in town received water and electricity from the services.She grown up and got married. As her and grandpa began building a family they got a land line phone! The “road” (basically a dirt path large enough for ox pulled carts) was paved and some public lighting was installed.My grandpa got a job at a factory in the city and eventually was able to buy a motorcycle, sparing him of the twice a day 2+h walk.They had four daughters and when they were at school, the richer family in town got a TV, that was of course a B&W. Public transportation began hauling passangers to the city twice a day.Her daughters grown up and got married. They now had a TV and there was two channels to choose from! Eletric appliances were everywhere and able to do just about anything!My parents began their own family and by the time I went to school color TV's entered our homes followed by the very first computer for home use, the Spectrum Sinclair…My grandmother was now struggling to keep up with all this new world of weird technology…Then came the PC's and shortly after the cellular phone. Using a PC was (and still is) something she can't do but cell phones were not that complicated…Then smartphones, next gen PC's, gaming consoles, GPS navigation, etc…None of this is something she can understand or use…Yes, me and my generation were lucky enough to ride the technology revolution, we grew up with it. My parents are now beginning to struggle with the newer things…We will be better prepared for what is coming…maybe!As my grandmother and my parents, I too will reach a certain point of technological evolution where I will not be able to follow tech and will be left behind. More so as the new revolution, driven by AI and the likes will be, once again, an exponential growth.No matter what's going to happen it will, probably, not be for us, rather for our children and grandchildren. I just hope we can steer technology in the right direction.

Answer: There are some liberties taken in the Expanse.A fusion drive system can create a horrendous amount of energy, but still needs to toss out some reaction mass to accelerate at 1G. The water tanks could provide mass for the thrusters, but the big Epstein Drives would need more mass to chuck out, and there’s a problem with stray neutrons and waste heat.Holographic displays without some projection medium are not entirely credible.And the micro-gravity on non-spinning moons is very low and would be hard to represent in fiction or on TV.In just a couple of hundred years, mankind seems to have shiftedThere are some liberties taken in the Expanse.A fusion drive system can create a horrendous amount of energy, but still needs to toss out some reaction mass to accelerate at 1G. The water tanks could provide mass for the thrusters, but the big Epstein Drives would need more mass to chuck out, and there’s a problem with stray neutrons and waste heat.Holographic displays without some projection medium are not entirely credible.And the micro-gravity on non-spinning moons is very low and would be hard to represent in fiction or on TV.In just a couple of hundred years, mankind seems to have shifted a buttload of infrastructure out into the belt.But let us be totally clear.The science and technology we see inStar Wars, Trek, Battlestar Galactica, Avatar, AlienThe ExpanseThe biological differences of the belters are not about genetics, but about developmental biology, grow a child in microgravity and they will not look like a child raised in 1G.The cultural diffrences are also entirely reasonable. In the UK there is a huge diversity of accents and dialects. And that’s in one country. Were those communities divided into seperate nations, with minimal contact, then a local belter dialect would be entirely likely.

Answer: The biological changes are spot on realistic!  The difference in gravity isn't the result of some evolutionary process, it's the inevitable result of living and being born in a low gravity environment.  Our bones and muscles don't develop to be any stronger than they need to be - within a single generation we'd see the physical divide between Belters, Martians, and Earthers and it would look very much like the one we see in the show, with the lower gravity inhabitants being much taller and more fragile.As for the tech, well, so far everything looks correct in terms of technical capacity.  TheThe biological changes are spot on realistic!  The difference in gravity isn't the result of some evolutionary process, it's the inevitable result of living and being born in a low gravity environment.  Our bones and muscles don't develop to be any stronger than they need to be - within a single generation we'd see the physical divide between Belters, Martians, and Earthers and it would look very much like the one we see in the show, with the lower gravity inhabitants being much taller and more fragile.As for the tech, well, so far everything looks correct in terms of technical capacity.  The Martian terraforming project is a sticking point for me, as it's not just a question of bringing in material.  Mars just isn't capable of supporting a thick atmosphere anymore, and no amount of surface renovation will change that.  I'm hoping that when they talk about terraforming what they really mean is massive enclosed domes that can support an earth-like atmosphere, but I'll give them that if I have to.  Their ships work and fight pretty much exactly like they should (though the idea of a "stealth ship" in space is a wee bit iffy) and their astroid stations rely on rotational gravity as opposed to some exotic tech.The language... eh, that does seem a little far out for me to have happened naturally given that languages seem to be becoming more stable, not less, but I can conceive of a new language being deliberately created and fostered as a means of establishing a new social and cultural identity.Really the only areas that I think it fails the technological realism test is in the consumer electronics.  Those little holographic displays they have that project an image in the air? Yeah, that just doesn't work.  You just can't do a volumentric projection onto a transparent medium like that.  I'd have preferred it if they just used transparent screens instead.

Answer: Is it so really?This comes totally down on your expectations for a country.There are registered 195 countries in the United Nations and 35 others who are either city-states or not fully recognized areas of the world.Here is the science ranking around the world from 1996–2019 over their published works at international reputable science magazines:Ranked at 20th place in the entire world category for 48 different Science disciplines…Ranked in Medicine field, especially in advancedThen let’s come for intellectual proIs it so really?This comes totally down on your expectations for a country.There are registered 195 countries in the United Nations and 35 others who are either city-states or not fully recognized areas of the world.Here is the science ranking around the world from 1996–2019 over their published works at international reputable science magazines:Ranked at 20th place in the entire world category for 48 different Science disciplines…Ranked in Medicine field, especially in advancedThen let’s come for intellectual property rights and inventions in the industrial field:It challenges countries in the Top 10 with a population of over 1 billion and some hundred millions and immense resources and money at home.Look at the per head distribution of their industrial property applications:The entire world is speaking about the phenomenon of China and the USA tries to stop them and their immense increase in technology lead but with useless results. We have discussed over the whole last year before Corona about Huawei and their 5 G technology which was subject to many conspiracy theories around the world, but especially in the west and many countries repositioned themselves against China and the company Huawei.Well, you know for example who is behind the important coding of 5 G technology?Professor Dr. Erdal Arikan (Bilkent University-Ankara)The biggest misconception of people is always with limited knowledge to compare apples with pears.What you were expecting, that Turkey outranks Germany in just 30 years in every field when the latter has lived the industrialization in the early 19th century, whereas Turkey went from mainly agricultural production to industrialization with the neo-liberal reforms in the 80s? Or it should have a higher count of development per capita with a mini-state Netherland which is surrounded with zero problems on its borders for more than 70 years and Turkey is located in one of the most volatile regions of the world?Turkey, despite its huge struggles inside and on its borders and with limited resources compared to many top countries in the world, has delivered a decent job over decades and is ranked in many scientific fields such as medicine, defense sector, civil and structural engineering in the TOP 10, in mechanical engineering in the Top 20, computer science in the TOP 30, and in overall rankings since more than 20 years in the TOP 20 of the world.So how many countries are in Europe as you have stated in your question?As I know 46 countries in total and from these, 28 members of the EU, but when I look into many lists and rankings, it seems, only a few have arrived over there, the rest is not visible.Why you, for example, think that the United States and Europe sell all of their top-notch weapons to all of the Middle Eastern countries when they on other hand only sell a part of it to Turkey and most of the time block the sales? Because with one they have nothing to fear, with the other one, it will not take long that they will be copied and something new comes out very fast.Don’t miss one thing, the China of Europe in that sense is for very long Turkey.Thanks.

Answer: I’m a 30 year resident of Turkey and recently spent a year in California and two winters in Switzerland. Upon return to Turkey, I was truly appreciative of how much easier life is in Turkey in many ways.BankingI’m a 30 year resident of Turkey and recently spent a year in California and two winters in Switzerland. Upon return to Turkey, I was truly appreciative of how much easier life is in Turkey in many ways.BankingPublic TransportationFoodIn the States, those vast supermarkets and bulk discount mega stores - ugh - where is the roadmap to navigate Costco? Produce - it may look like a tomato, but it sure doesn’t taste like a tomato. Want some hummus? You’ll have to buy a pound of it A baguette to go with dinner? That’ll be 3 dollars please. And don’t get me started on eating out. All the mid-rage (West Coast) eateries seem to have the same basic menu with a couple of permutations. Ruby’s, Applebee’s, Chili’s, Marie Calendar - ‘’Would you like Ranch, Italian or Blue Cheese dressing with your chicken caesar salad?’’ And for your 10 dollar salad, you could feed a village in - well - most other countries. But wait - Everest size salad has arrived….and so has the bill! Cindy’s shift is over so she wants to know if she can get you any dessert before she speeds off to yoga in her giant SUV. ‘It’s ok Cindy - I’ll just sprinkle some brown sugar on my salad for dessert.’’In Switzerland, don’t be hungry between 1400 and 1800, or settle for a cold supermarket sandwich (Vaud.) Swiss food itself? Yummy for about a week, after which you are either broke, bored, or both. Need to catch up on laundry or housecleaning? Not after 2000, and never, ever on a Sunday.LaborFriendships & NeighborsTo try and answer the original question, Turkey is an enigma.Hope readers don’t take anything I’ve said too seriously - love all three countries in their own way.
